comments.commentBody:
I found the theme especially clever. Great job Alex and Will.

I hope none of the oldsters were "baffled" by UNO.
It looks like bureaucracy as usual with Administrators doing all they can to assure preservation of their jobs, even if it means firing or not rehiring needed teachers and other schoolroom staff.

Clearly this was not Congress' intent. The funds from the Federal government should go to rehiring teachers that were laid off. I would ask that the Dept of Education (at the Federal level) make sure that the funds are distributed to each state to make sure they are effective for educating children NOW. The worry in the states about funding in the future is a sure sign of governmental "disinflation" - hoping that salaries and benefits for teachers can be pushed down.
State governments are not profit making entities - they are supposes to use funds to provide services - and education should be top priority in the service department.
As a resident of NJ - where my newly elected governor cut 90 million to higher education and almost 900 million to K-12 education - the injection of funds from the feds could make a big difference in the quality of education my children will receive.
I am sick and tired of hearing of the deficit - let's get the economic engine moving and we can grind down the deficit if we don't keep going to war.
What a waste, when this money could have gone to the rich who deserve it..

What's so sacred about school teachers? I mean really. Many of the  folks who  have lost their jobs in this downturn are contractors, sub- contractors, on call  waiters,  mechanics, carpenters, etc. In many instances they are not even eligible for unemployment.  So what happens to them? I have a feeling we will find out come November.
The government should add a stipulation that if the money is not used to save teachers jobs, it has to be returned.

The technology is great. Solar powered mass transit is a win/win situation for any country.
Yet, I can't help but think that 1,200 passengers in a bus would make for a fairly horriffic bus accident.
I would rethink the scale. Ultimately the future is going to be a better place when we don't need a 1,200 passenger bus. But as long as China is stuck with her 1,200,000,000 souls, she'll be needing them.
Wouldn't it be great if there were constantly rotating dim sum carts with yummy snacks inside? No seriously- mmmm...dim sum. : )

Its really unconscionable that this is happening.  The Congress appropriated money for a particular purpose at a particular time and the recipients of the money are refusing to spend it as directed.  The only thing that I can think of which will force the States to use the money for the specified purpose would be to take it back.  If the States come up with a problem next year than they will have to deal with it at that time.  Right now we are in the throes of what may turn out to be a double dip recession and the money must be spent to keep our children educated, not to help the administrators of the largest states sleeping well at night.  If they can't sleep there are plenty of medications they can turn to; I would recommend a warm milk laced with brandy to start.
They need to save the money to donate it back to the Democratic party.  That is how such things work in this country.

Teachers in CA must be notified of layoffs by March 15th of the prior year. Negotiations with Unions over salary, benefits, and class sizes had to be done before June. Of course the money now comes too late. District administrators, notorious for shifting and hiding funds, will "claim" they are stockpiling for the next round of cuts.
As a middle school language arts and social studies teacher now facing 38 students per class with up to 215 per day, and having seven less days in the school year (unpaid furlough days), I hope the money has some conditions attached to it.
As it is, very few people realize that from city to city, town to town and district to district, administrators and school boards set budgets, days in school and teacher pay in vastly different ways. Wealthier districts surrounding my district have made no cuts in services while our teachers gave pay, days, benefits, and class size. Why this money couldn't have come months sooner just demonstrates how alienated the Federal and State governments are.
Who loses? Not just laid off teachers but, more importantly, the students. Shouldn't they be the focus and the real purpose of education?

How much of this is the Teachers Union wanting to preserve jobs that aren't needed? Let's not forget that Los Angeles Unified and many other schools around LA have DECLINING enrollment. Much of this frantic hiring at the LAUSD was directly linked to these enrollment predictions that haven't panned out.
I agree with the skeptics on this one. There are lots of obvious problems this proposal, and essentially no advantages relative to the much simpler idea of putting large buses on the roadway.
New Hampshire doesn't expect to spend any of the stimulus on teachers, but will use the money to pay down existing debt!

This article clearly demonstrates that this money was nothing but an election year ploy to get teachers' unions and other Democratic interest groups out for the election this fall. When will the reckless spending stop?

http://blog.heritage.org...

So the money isn't to support the supposed dire need to rehire teachers this fall after all? And they've got until 2012 to use it? Now we see yet another hoax that has been perpetrated on ordinary Americans by politicians who have great trouble speaking the truth.

How much longer will we put up with the current politicians who repeatedly and deliberately misrepresent issues just to grab more money from taxpayers or the needy to spend, spend, spend? Didn't Democrats agree to cut food stamps to "pay" for this money grab that isn't going to be used for what they said? How much more despicable can they get?

This stinks, but it's no surprise, and there is wisdom in it. Harsh choices must be made, there's no way to please everyone (or anyone), and I don't envy administrators or teachers one bit right now. Given the political climate, the latest funds may be the last for a while, so yeah...maybe it is smart to wait and see, since this may prevent a far worse disaster in the coming months.

I am certain of this...I flip the radio dial to Rush and his ilk every now and then, just to hear what's going on in "real America" as they call themselves. Why I do this I don't know, because my blood pressure must boil over every time he croaks about how this money is just a political handout to save unions and their pension. How is it some people get such a thrill, and indeed earn such a fortune, off breeding hatred, resentment, and fear? It's a sad, incredibly frustrating time when the far Right is able to make everything so much worse with all its garbage.

Abolish the present educational funding system and issue every parent education vouchers. This will stimulate true competition in terms of educational quality, and will give even the neediest kids in the seediest neighborhoods some semblance of educational equality. The present system benefits only teachers, their unions, and the staggering layers of bureaucracy that result in some schools actually having more administrators than classroom teachers.

I attended a Catholic elementary school that had more than 700 students. The staff consisted of the teachers, the principal, one nurse, one guidance counselor, one speech pathologist, two secretaries, two cooks, and two janitors.

When I graduated, I attended a public high school, and was immediately blown away by the huge cadre of department heads, chairpersons, assistant principals, deans, secretaries, and so forth who took up an entire floor of the school. Rarely did any of these people set foot in a classroom, and had they all been fired en masse I doubt anyone would have noticed.

Catholic and other parochial schools educate children at an average of one-third to one-half the cost of public schools. Once upon a time, this was because most of the teachers were nuns and brothers who were paid peanuts. But those days are over. The difference in pay between private and public school teachers has narrowed quite a bit and only accounts for a fraction of the total difference in educational cost. The bulk of the difference is due to the waste, inefficiency, and bureaucracy that typifies public education.

So why reward inefficiency at the expense of children? Move to vouchers, force schools to compete on the quality of the education they provide, and give poor children a chance to attend decent schools rather than being enslaved to whatever school happens to "serve" their neighborhood.

-LL

Very cool.  And make all those designated lanes underneath this wide skybus: bike lanes.  Cyclists can travel so fast when there are no cars in the way.  Greener, too.  And more fun.  Not to mention safer for the cyclists.

This is precisely what happens to federal government programs that are not thought out carefully. Why have a legislature if they don't have the capacity to write intelligent laws?

And if you think that this legislation is bad, wait until the HHS published all the details that Congress dumped in their laps. Perhaps we should vote for the Cabinet members if Congress is going to shirk their legislative role.
David, I was 9 years old and a devout NY Giants fan. I came home from school and sat by the TV watching the ending of the greatest game I have ever seen -- bar none.

When the rural Republicans took away the nomination for someone who can unseat Harry Reid with ease, namely Sue Lowden, with the help of the Tea Party, they in essence handed the senate seat back to Harry Reid.  Sharon Angle is exactly like her supporters, short-sighted and have no clue of the big picture.  At the end, we squandered away our chance to send HR packing come November.

The idea that Jefferson and Franklin were conservatives is laughable. One need only look at the way Franklin behaved in Paris to know he was no conservative. Jefferson overturned centuries of social norms by elevating the rights of individuals over the prerogatives of royalty.

As for Washington, he was instrumental in driving the colonies deep into debt to fund the revolutionary war. Necessary? Absolutely. Conservative? Not by a long shot.
What a waste of money.

The Problems with Democrats is that they become smug in their pride of fighting for people like Harry Reid.

The idea that anyone would fight for Harry Reid is beyond reason.

No sane, intelligent, informed individual would ever vote for Harry Reid.

All you have to do is research Harry Reid, and you'd see what kind of man he really is.
Revolting and pathetic. There us NO justice, just  tons of wasted talk and taxpayer money.
